summary: Alan G. Sentinella was a retired FBI Special Agent who testified before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) in May and June of 1975. His testimony primarily concerned FBI investigations into Martin Luther King Jr., the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC), and Stanley Levison. The documents summarize his recollections and details his involvement in these investigations, focusing on aspects such as electronic surveillance, potential communist influence, and the FBI's operational policies. Sentinella's testimony provides insights into the FBI's activities during this period and their focus on individuals and organizations perceived as threats.
significance: While the documents provided do not directly link Alan G. Sentinella to the JFK assassination, his testimony before the Senate Select Committee (SSC) provides context regarding FBI investigations and surveillance activities during the 1960s and 1970s. This information could be relevant to understanding the broader political and investigative landscape surrounding the JFK assassination, particularly concerning potential government surveillance and intelligence operations.
